title: Trying to Reconnect on a Mac
body:
So I can log on into Leage but as soon as the Game opens there is a popup saying:
"Trying to reconnect...
We're attempting to automatically reconnect you to League of Legends. If tour Internet connection is otherwise ok, check our support page for possible solutions.
Exit Instead"

I then downloaded the Hextech Repair tool but nothing happened.

replies.body: The HRT can help repair files and run logs, but this issue seems more related to your connection.  More specifically, your network seems to be unstable and losing comms with the game server.  Your best bet would be to run over each step of the [connection issues](https://support.riotgames.com/hc/en-us/articles/201752664-Troubleshooting-Connection-Issues) guide for the fix, and then test it in a custom game.  I hope that helps!

I found a method to reproduce the bug. I'm usually connected to my local WiFi with a bandwith of 300 MBit/s, representing a MCS-Index of 15. This index can be shown on a Mac holding the alt-Key while pressing the WiFi Button located at the status bar of the Mac. I realised that when I'm disconnecting myself from the local area, accessing internet by mobile hotspot, my MCS-Index fell below equal 7, resulting in a connection to the internet via only one stream. Every time my connection reduced to a single stream, my League client could connect successfully to the home screen of the launcher. This may also explain the randomness of time needed to reconnect after launching the game with more than a single stream. I set up the hotspot where I'm connecting to with my Mac usually by my iPhone, only the last time I connected with a expending WiFi hotspot by Windows. The hotspot set up by WIndows had been connected to the same WiFi I'd usually been connecting to with my Mac, so it's definitly not a error on local network side. While my Windows hotspot was strong enough to open two streams, I couldn't connect without the 'Trying to reconnect...' message. Only when it dropped down to one stream, I could connect successfully.
For more information about the Streams and the MCS-Index see https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IEEE_802.11n-2009#Data_rates
Reducing the MCS-Index can be archived by lowering the signal strengh, e.g. through body-blocking.

Just wanted to shout out that the problem is still there. Although, for the moment being the idea suggested by Zyreon seems like the only one to work so far.

2. Log-in to League through the "hotspot"
3. Switch back to your usual wifi.
